oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Glen Haven Souvenir Postcard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Glen Haven as seen from the opposite shore. The Glen Haven Senitarium (1847-1911) was tucked between a 1,200 foot embankment and Skaneateles Lake. Visitors seeking the "water cure" were offered a quiet, healthy environment to escape the heat and noise of city- dwelling in the 1850s.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards; Therapeutic communities; Lakes;
Community & Events; Daily Life; Recreation & Sports;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Please cite as: Skaneateles Historical Society's Skaneateles Lake Collection. For usage beyond Fair Use, please contact the holding institution.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Glen Haven Hotel Mail Card
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The grandeur of the Glen Haven Hotel. The hotel could accomodate 200 or more guests offering large, airy rooms and elegant furnishings. Additional buildings and cottages were also devoted to patient care.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards; Hotels; lakes
Community & Events; Daily Life;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Please cite as: Skaneateles Historical Society's Skaneateles Lake Collection. For usage beyond Fair Use, please contact the holding institution.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Glen Haven Stereoscopic Card
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of families by cottage. Families sought hydrotherapy to find relief from unnatural artificial lifestyles by alternative health treatments.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wildey, O. H. (Photographer)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Families seated outside of cottage.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. W. C. Thomas Photograph
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. W. C. Thomas was the proprietor of the Glen Haven "water cure" from 1860-1900. The treatment included half baths; dips in the cold lake; healthy eating with no coffee, tea or liquid; and drinking large amounts of water to cleanse the system.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photograph of seated Dr. Thomas with child and dog in background.
Physicians; Dogs; Children; Hydrotherapy
People;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Photograph with handwritten elements on back.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Please cite as: Skaneateles Historical Society's Skaneateles Lake Collection. For usage beyond Fair Use, please contact the holding institution.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bear Swamp is an integral part of the Skaneateles Lake Watershed. Today Bear Swamp is a state forest open year round to the public.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Drilling in Bear Swamp" Newspaper Clipping
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper article and photograph about drilling in Bear Swamp. The state bought much of the land and planted balsam and spruce trees in the 1930's. Deer, turkeys, waterfowl, foxes, and coyotes are abundant. Bear Swamp is an integral part of the Skaneateles Lake Watershed. In 2005, natural gas and oil exploration at this site was a topic of discussion. Today fracking is a major concern threatening the quality of our natural resources.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hacken, Liz
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: newspapers; Drilling platforms; Oil fields;
Government, Law & Politics; Environment & Nature;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Newspaper article in The Citizen with photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Please cite as: Skaneateles Historical Society's Skaneateles Lake Collection. For usage beyond Fair Use, please contact the holding institution.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bear Swamp Offers Undisturbed Wildlife Newspaper clipping
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portion of newspaper article and photograph of Bear Swamp in winter. Today Bear Swamp is a state forest. It is open year-round to the public and trail maps are located at the entrance for hiking in fair weather and cross-country skiing for snowy days.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cannerelli, Stephen D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forest reserves; Forest roads; newspapers
Geography & Maps; Environment & Nature;

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Just north of One Mile Point stands the Skaneateles Country Club, begun as a golf club in 1915. The original clubhouse was finished in 1917.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newspaper Photographs by Herbert Baker
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Top photograph shows the view of Skaneateles Lake from the home of late Captain George Collins, his wife is at the left of the photograph. The bottom photograph shows visitors coming to camp near Spafford Landing. Captain George Collins, a Union officer, was born in Spafford Corners in 1837. He and his family arrived at Spafford Landing by boat and built the first private cottage on the Lake in 1880.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Baker, Herbert N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: cottages; lakes; newspapers
Daily Life; Geography & Maps;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Two photographs and captions featured in a newspaper clipping.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Please cite as: Skaneateles Historical Society's Skaneateles Lake Collection. For usage beyond Fair Use, please contact the holding institution.
